query: What is the regularity of the ideal (x^3 + y^3) in k[x, y]? How about in k[x, y, z]?
response:
To determine the regularity of the ideal (x^3 + y^3) in both \( k[x, y] \) and \( k[x, y, z] \), we examine the length of the associated modules. For a graded module over a polynomial ring, the length corresponds to its degree. Hence, the degree of the ideal (x^3 + y^3) provides the necessary information about its regularity.  

The ideal (x^3 + y^3) has minimal generators that lead to a degree of 3, indicating that the regularity in both rings is 3, as the degree of the generator is dominant in determining the regularity.
references: [functions\degree-doc.m2] If m is a graded module over a polynomial ring, the length is the same as the degree.

Hence, the degree of the ideal (x^3 + y^3) provides the necessary information about its regularity.  \n\nThe ideal (x^3 + y^3) has minimal generators that lead to a degree of 3, indicating that the regularity in both rings is 3, as the degree of the generator is dominant in determining the regularity.","references":["[functions\\degree-doc.m2] If m is a graded module over a polynomial ring, the length is the same as the degree."]}

result.headline: convert a monomial ideal to an ideal
convert a module to an ideal
compute the length of a module
result.usage:
l = length m
inputs
  m: module
outputs
  l: zz
    the length of m
result.description:
text
    if m is a graded module over a singly graded polynomial ring or a quotient of a
    polynomial ring over a field k then length is the same as the degree.

    if m is over a local ring then length is computed by summing the output of
    the hilbert-samuel function until it vanishes. note that in this case the
    @to "localrings :: localrings"@ package must be loaded first.
consequences
  item
    in the local case, the length of the module is stored in m.cache.length.

tool_responses.name: summarize_docs
tool_responses.result:
Here are the most relevant documentation details:
- **length, module**: If m is a graded module over a singly graded polynomial ring or a quotient of a polynomial ring over a field k then length is the same as the degree.
